"State Capitalism" is an oxymoron.  It's an impossibility, like "Satanist Christian" or "Intelligent socialist."  It's something that socialists make up in a desperate attempt to employ the "No True Scotsman" fallacy.

Naturally, social democracy and socialism are not at all related.  The entire point of a social democracy is a capitalist economy.  It's a poor system that works badly, but it's still not socialism.

replies.author: @Kingoftherednex
replies.text:
@willguggn2 

"I tend to adopt what's established in academia"
Such as attempts to No-True-Scotsman away all of socialism's failures?

"There's always been a vocal struggle about how socialism could be established, and social democrats have been a significant part of it historically"
No.  That's plain and simply not true.  You can't simply change the labels around to try to create successes and remove failures.

"though authoritarian socialists 'won' over libertarian socialists in the well known, failed instances. "
This is a common socialist trope.  It's false.  When the "libertarian socialists" (another complete oxymoron, as socialists attempt to hijack libertarianism) had their way--Ukraine, Catalonia, Paris, and others--it was still mostly murdering and starving.

"If you only call the latter true socialists, what would you call the former?"
Some false term, because the latter are also socialists.  They're just as true to socialism as the latter, and followed Marx' ideals better.

Socialism is not one extremely-narrowly defined system, any more than I could say the USA doesn't have capitalism because I can't buy and sell heroin.  There are several varieties of socialism, and all of them are utter failures.

"But somehow your standard for democracies and anarchies seem to be dependant on the outcome conforming to those ideals"
It ain't.  When the outcome of socialism conforms to the ideals of its founders (the ones they state, not their true "punish people for being successful when I couldn't" goals), the state is still a failure.

Also, socialism isn't being held to a different standard.  If democracy turned out to be a complete, miserable, tyrannical, deadly failure every single time it was tried without exception, then I'd be supporting monarchy.

"(Oh, is John Maynard Keynes a socialist to you?)
Of course not.  Keynes was a power-hungry idiot who knew nothing of economics, but just because every socialist is a power-hungry idiot who knows nothing of economics, doesn't mean that every power-hungry idiot who knows nothing of economics is a socialist.

Keynes wasn't a very good capitalist, and a society built according to his principles would drag with constant boom and bust cycles--but it would still be far better than any socialist system.

replies.text:
@Kingoftherednex 
Sorry, i think completely misread a few of your paragraphs when i tried to condense your points as I understood them. 



I still don't deny real socialism as in Leninism etc.; their outcomes just didn't fulfill any socialist goals. 



Giving power to the worker over the means of production, away from private ownership, is socialist. Legislation empowering unions through legislation does just that. As does free access to education and free access to modern medicine. It's decoupling of power/knowledge/existential freedom from personal wealth to a degree a free market economy cannot grant. 



If democracy and socialism were mutually exclusive, Marx and Engels weren't socialists. Both stated democracy as a necessary outcome of socialism/communism; even proposed reformative socialism through existing democracy in some countries they believed had a strong enough, democratic foundation, where revolution in favour of the working class wasn't necessary. (They did heavily criticise early socialists (coined utopian socialists) for believing democracy could work in and of itself in Germany, though.) Socialism supposedly leads to communism, when capitalism inevitably breaks down. (Which it obviously doesn't.) 



And yes, capitalism is more than just free-market-capitalism. 



Real socialists never effectively abolished capitalism per se. They crushed the free market by state monopoly and cartels, shifting wealth and power from a few to even fewer functionaries, the effective owners, which inevitably destroyed their economies.

replies.author: @Kingoftherednex
replies.text:
Their outcomes had government control of the economy.  That's socialism's goal.  It didn't create a utopia, but that's because socialism doesn't do that.

When a rain dance doesn't make rain, we don't decide it must have been something with their technique; we acknowledge that rain dances don't work.

Meanwhile, socialism is a system in which control of the means of production is taken away from the people who created it.  Pretending that anything that you like is therefore socialist is just plain ridiculous.  

Also, the idea that socialism decouples power, knowledge, and freedom from personal wealth is equally ridiculous.  If you really want to see income inequality, look at any socialist country.

Look at the Soviet Union, where Stalin had dozens of mansions and a staff of servants for each while half of Russian hospitals didn't have running water.

Look at Venezuela, where Maduro's daughter has $4 billion in her bank account while the people literally fight over the best garbage-picking grounds.

Look at North Korea, where the Kim dynasty tills tons of sugar into the soil to make their apples sweeter while the military has recently lowered their height requirements to 4'8" because of malnutrition.  

Look at Cuba, where Castro's family pretty much lives on yachts while 14- and 15-year-old girls are prostituting themselves for literally two bucks a throw.

Look at China, where people with the right positions in government are raking in millions and sending their kids to American schools while those the government doesn't favor starve.

It's almost as funny as watching y'all talk about "fighting imperialism" when you refer to Cuba, North Korea, and other military outposts of the Soviet Union.

It's the same wishful thinking that has every socialist certain that he or she will be writing slam poetry For the People instead of working 15 hours a day in a crumbling steel mill and then coming home to help your wife shoo rats away from the baby.

"If democracy and socialism were mutually exclusive, Marx and Engels weren't socialists. Both stated democracy as a necessary outcome of socialism/communism;"
LOL no.  

Marx wrote that there would eventually be a democracy, but that before then there was a "dictatorship of the proletariat" until people were brainwashed into voting the way they were "supposed to."

"between capitalist and communist society there lies the period of the revolutionary transformation of the one into the other. Corresponding to this is also a political transition period in which the state can be nothing but the revolutionary dictatorship of the proletariat"

That's why socialist countries rant about the "revolution" and "revolutionaries" long after they've finished creating a socialist state.  As long as the revolution is still ongoing, the dictatorship is still necessary; for your own good.

That's why wherever socialism was installed, it was done so either by fraud or by force.  To claim that socialists support democracy is to be willfully blind.

Note that Marx and Engels were both clear that some people would simply never become good socialists and would have to be "eliminated."  Amusingly, they thought the Russians were one of those groups.

Racial classifications made on the basis of phenotypes are not scientifically sound and are purely social constructs. I have no opinions on race as a social construct. Who is and isn't labeled as white is not important to me. Though I will say that many Jews, particularly orthodox Jews, will not see themselves as white even if whites classify them as such. "a place in which large numbers of people, especially political prisoners or members of persecuted minorities, are deliberately imprisoned in a relatively small area with inadequate facilities, sometimes to provide forced labour or to await mass execution. author: @ryanmorton3841
text:
Watching you skewering right-wing talking heads whilst maintaining your cool has been delightful. I'm ashamed to admit that there was a period wherein I bought into some of the talking points of some of the "tamer" right-leaning YouTubers, like the so-called "classical liberals" and pseudo-sceptics, but even then I couldn't escape the feeling that there was something off about them, I even actively avoided their more obviously extreme cohorts as their shit could be smelled from a mile away and then it just clicked. Just because they said a few things that I agreed with I was suddenly allowing myself to ignore all of their demonstrable bullshit that I knew I didn't buy into. 

So while you probably won't be able to rationally convince the irrational reactionaries, conspiracy theorists and hardline bigots I think content like yours acts like a well-deserved slap in the face to those that should and usually do know better and it's always nice watching right-wingers get demolished..... I mean debunked. So for that, I thank you and I hope I didn't come off as a sycophant.

@piedpiper6425 shame that person didn't respond to your question, but I would be glad to. "Modern feminism" is a giant movement that anyone can participate in and to claim that there is cohesion and agreement among everyone who aligns itself with it and their beliefs would be grossly oversimplifying it. When it comes to invalidating experiences of men, most feminists see men and women as being equally valid in their experience, but simply women as in a worse position than men due to the patriarchy and thus in need of more attention, care and etc. Feminists who do dismiss and invalidate men are often trans-exclusionary-radical-feminists (TERFs), but these people are in a great minority and should not make you reject the movement as a whole. 
It should also be noted that most other feminists reject TERFs as well.

replies.text:
@Human Rights Watch The New Deal recipe for reducing the Great Depression, and to minimize future recessions and depressions, was to give money to consumers who lacked money with which to consume output. 

This was after the credit-driven speculation bubble had swelled and collapsed. This not only shrank the overall money supply, consisting of high-powered govt dollars plus the much larger credit supply, but also increased overall debt levels after the Crash as asset values continued to collapse and shrink fast.

The Old Deal was for govt to subsidize top wealthy capitalists and large Corporations directly, typically via war production and other channels.

The New Deal was to help consumer-driven businesses indirectly, by Trickle Up economics instead of Trickle Down. 

Key conservatives joined with FDR, such as Mariner Eccles. The CEO of GE joined his team. Other conservatives did, and still do, adhere to principles and myths that capitalism will always magically and naturally fix itself, like examples in physics, biology, and religion.

But the problem was the collapse of DEMAND (refuting Says Law that Supply always creates Demand), which is always partly fueled by credit-creation (out of thin air) as well as Govt spending (out of thin air).

Your point about encouraging idleness and stupidity is noted.

That raises the last point, that Govt spending CANNOT come from wealthy people, as no person of wealth or labor has ever created even one United States Dollars. (Nor has China. They spend to create and distribute Yuan.)

Taxes too high a/o net spending too low is always now the cause of unemployment. *Govt has infinite means to spend as needed* when bank credit creation is weak or in contraction. We know this from 20th century decades of war, including Cold War spending totaling $12 Trillion after 1945. That $12 Trillion was mostly added to the US economy, under patriotism. (Not sure what it would be in today's dollars.)

(The economy does not have infinite capacity to utilize infinite annual fiscal deficits. There's not infinite shit to buy.)

But if Trickle Down worked as stated, those with little or no money would be able to boost GDP by going shopping if for example Congress gave one man, Donald Trump, his entire $5 Trillion fiscal deficit, to spend personally as he saw fit.

Nor is consumption boosted effectively when corporate tax cuts go to stock buyback schemes, which used to be barred as fraud. That is, using corporate windfalls to artificial manipulate share prices up, creating frenzy, and fattening gains for executive shareholders.

This has nothing in common with traditional concepts of noble capitalism: investments, improvements, production, and sales of useful products to consumers. It's more pure financial gimmickry writ large, more like Madoff, not like Sanders.

sorry wordsof harmony, but you haven't quite got it right.
Being a communist is naturally extreme, it's just that many of the proponents we're exposed to are reasonably well-raised, involved w/ arts/humanities in University and are products of a mixed economy & state, resulting in their conduct being much like everyone else's, broadly speaking. Though there's also the unapologetically thuggish communists in the likes of Antifa, whom the previously mentioned communists almost universally support.
That is evidence of natural extremity right there, in that when it comes to tactics not dissimilar from what the extremist political groups of the 20th century employed, there's a dedicated sect willing to do the same in the name of THEIR cause, while the rest of the group are quite happy about it and will do nothing to stop it - and some end up joining in as it becomes normalised and the social propaganda flows.
Many communists do not believe themselves to be inherently violent, naturally extreme or vicious or what-have-you, because in their minds they're taking a stand against what they perceive to be the evils of the profit-driven, industrialized No-Mans-Land that regards people as little more than economic units, which disgusts the communists' sensibilities.
They hate those that actively praise and propel the capitalist system and come to look upon those who don't care w/ a unique loathing.
The communist in practice is a vile and vicious creature, largely due to its' believing that its' efforts are in everyone's' best interests.
Those who would stamp on the workers' revolution? it's for the greater good that they are taken out. It's the very belief that they are relieving humanity of the perilous, evil matrix of capitalism that ensures extremity once things are underway and there are stakes.

What you said about Nazis is mainly true, though only because you used the word Nazi instead of the term National Socialist or Fascist.
To the Nazi (while it's short for National Socialist we know someone using the word is referencing a person who is partial to Hitlers slant) the use of violence in some capacity is required as the goals of the Party were to remove Jews and Slavs from Europe.
That COULD be done w/o genocide, at least theoretically... unlikely as it is, but it couldn't be done w/o a degree of violence.
Fascism and/or National Socialism, however, do not HAVE to involve such extremes. In part, this is because Fascism is not a real ideology, but a kind of collection of sentiments and tactics that aren't concrete. It's really a term that's more useful for the audience/the critic than anyone else as it is used more or less to get the alarms ready once certain tactics and the like are observed.
I've heard that there were many who eagerly joined up w/ the Nazis, once Germany had taken Europe, who didn't care for the vicious hatred of Slavs that many of the Germans - Hitler especially - had, but really resonated w/ the socio-cultural aspects. There have been rather a few peoples who've operated very similarly to the National Socialist way in their tribes/societies, w/o the need, or want, for genocide.
Many in subsequent years have come to regard the internal mechanics of Nazi Germany as optimal for a society, though of course they tend to not include the blatant eugenics and all the rest.
